title: Hassan Shehata
text:
Hassan Shehata (; born 19 June 1949) is an Egyptian former professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. Before retirement he played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>. He then became a football manager, who is now retired. Shehata led Egypt to victory in 3 titles, all which were at the African Cup of Nations: 2006, 2008 and 2010. He was the first ever coach to win three consecutive Africa Cup of Nations titles. Shehata is one of only two coaches to win the Africa Cup 3 times, along with Ghana's <a href="Charles%20Gyamfi">Charles Gyamfi</a>.
Managerial career.
In 2004, Shehata became <a href="Egypt%20national%20football%20team">Egypt's national team</a> coach after the sacking of <a href="Italians">Italian</a> coach <a href="Marco%20Tardelli">Marco Tardelli</a>. In the <a href="2006%20African%20Cup%20of%20Nations">2006 African Cup of Nations</a>, hosted by <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, he led the team to its first Cup of Nations in eight years, defeating the <a href="Ivory%20Coast%20national%20football%20team">Ivory Coast</a> in the final.
During the African Cup semi-final against <a href="Senegal%20national%20football%20team">Senegal</a>, Shehata had a serious argument with one of his players, <a href="Mido%20%28footballer%29">Mido</a>. That was a resultant of Mido reacting negatively to being substituted. Shehata was vindicated minutes later when <a href="Amr%20Zaki">Amr Zaki</a>, the player replacing Mido, scored the winning goal; which took Egypt to the final. Shehata did allow Mido to accept his medal at the closing ceremonies of the African Cup of Nations. Following the incident in a few days, Mido issued a public apology.
As mentioned earlier, Shehata led Egypt to three successive titles at the <a href="African%20Cup%20of%20Nations">African Cup of Nations</a> in <a href="2006%20Africa%20Cup%20of%20Nations">2006</a>, <a href="2008%20Africa%20Cup%20of%20Nations">2008</a> and <a href="2010%20Africa%20Cup%20of%20Nations">2010</a>. Thus, Egypt became the first African nation to achieve such record. Consequently, the Egyptian team were ranked as high as 9th in the <a href="FIFA%20World%20Rankings">FIFA World Rankings</a>. Due to his great coaching ability throughout during that period, In 2008, he was awarded the title of <a href="CAF%20Awards">CAF Coach of the Year</a>.
In 2010, <a href="International%20Federation%20of%20Football%20History%20%26amp%3B%20Statistics">FFHSI</a> had ranked him as the best African Coach. He was also selected as one of the top five African coaches internationally.
In 2015, he became President of the SATUC Football Cup, a new charitable global football competition for U16 orphans, refugees and disadvantaged children.
